title: in need of guidance, criticism and suggestions
content:
Somehow the elegance this began with is gone, now it feels clunky. I think perhaps I let the extreme contrast of a Didot influence me, then over compensated. I need a fresh perspective on this. Also, sorry about the name, I suck at naming fonts. Feel free to offer an alternative.

Thanks!  
-Noah

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |

author: grod

comments.content: Your attachment does not appear. There is a problem with the file or it is another kind of problem. Can you return a gif or a jpeg?

Strange, it works for me. Try [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/kisbefeSans.pdf "link to pdf sample"). Here is a raster version of the pdf:  
 [page 1](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/kisbefeSansRasterSampleP1of.gif "153Kb gif")  
 [page 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/kisbefeSansRasterSampleP2of.gif "252Kb gif"). Hope these work better for you.

Having the e be a rotation of the a (or vice versa) is a neat idea that is totally not working here. "hamburgefons" is an eyesore as a result. I think, at the very least, the counters need to be larger in order for those letterforms to work. The top of the Q feels sawn off rather than flattened. The figures are ungainly. They either need to be smoothed out or made more geometric; they're lumpy now. I like the g, m, and w. Is the x supposed to be leaning to the right?

Right now it feels more like [Eurostile](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Eurostile), [Microgramma](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Microgramma), or [Bank Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Bank%20Gothic) more than a [didone](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/typophile.com/wiki/didone), mostly because the curves of the bowls and lobes undercuts the contrast in the strokes. It also feels a little like [Peignot](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Peignot), with the unusual variations in heights and letterforms. I think what it really needs is to have a coat of consistency slapped over it, and then see what direction you want to take it. It's not boring, but it has no idea what it wants to be when it grows up.

Forrest, aside from the Q, are there any other characters that stick out as being in need of work? You say a coat of consistency, which forms do you think I should take as the model to bring the rest of the face in line with? Rather than making idiotic sample sheets all the time, here's the [glyph table](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/allglyphs "FontLab Glyph printout") Thank you for taking the time to comment, it is very much appreciated.  
-Noah

Interesting font. I have some comments. The a and e would be to work again. They do not seem to be a part of the same family. I also suggest of worked again the letter B. I believe that you do not have to cut the top and not use a broken straight line in the center. Good work

What do you think of the a, e, B, Q, and s now?  
 [here are all the glyphs again](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/allglyphs_01.pdf "revision")
It's better. I would reduce a bit the height of the bowl of the a. Do you plan to keep the @ as it is or to use the new a?

I'd try smoothing all contours a little bit because all irregular shapes tend to catch the eye too much for a comfortable reading. Proportions in general seem ok but the geometric origin seems way too evident to me. Good luck! Lowercase "a" and "e" need to be checked, as well as lowercase 3, 5, 6 and 8.
the a is giving me a hard time. any of [these three](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/a.pdf "pdf link") look good?

I started working on the Greek characters. Only thing is, I don't know Greek from greek. So if someone more knowledgeable would care to comment, I'd appreciate it. [the glyphs are here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/um2.pdf "Greek Characters Draft zero from Kisbefe Sans").  
**EDIT**  
After a bunch more hours of work, I've made some headway. As you can see I've started working on the Russian letters, though they aren't all there yet. [Here is the printout of all they glyphs](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/glyphTable.pdf "all characters as of 21 May 05, 7AM")

Kisbefe Sans and my text face, n!samual, [play well together](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/stupid1.pdf "Zine Cover MockUp"), I think. Anyone care explain how to go about selling fonts (not that these are quite ready, but they're getting there), I'm clueless. _note, pdf is 3.24mb_ **edit** I'm stupid and forgot to check "crop image data to frames" file is now reasonable sized. On a related note, it would be nice if the **\<strike\>** tag were enabled for this type of "oops" moment.
Concerning your three a, I will keep the number 1. I would use the number 3, in the italic. I believe that the curve of the top should be less curved.

Well, I've started working on the bold, but I think perhaps what I'm really making is a demi bold. take a look see and let me know what you think. **[sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/boldtest0.pdf)**

just so you know, the problem people had with the pdf was the fact that you had 2 fullstops before the file type "kisbefeSans..pdf" rather than "kisbefeSans.pdf". an easy fix would be for whoever downloaded it to simply delete the 2nd fullstop but many windows users don't realise this.

Dear all,  
Here is a [revised version of Kisbefe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123211313/http:/www.grodworks.com/temp/kisbefe_new.pdf) and two new weights. I'm sorry the hinting is rather bad at the moment so if you don't want to print it you'll need to zoom in like, 600%. Please comment.  
-Noah
